laws.summary: Rhode Island prohibits employers from asking applicants about wage or salary history and from relying on such information to determine compensation.
requirements: Employers may not inquire about an applicant’s wage or salary history
Employers may not seek wage history from current or former employers
Applicants may voluntarily disclose wage history without prompting
Employers may confirm wage history only if voluntarily disclosed
Retaliation for refusing to disclose wage history is prohibited
laws.notes: Rhode Island has one of the earlier enacted salary history bans in the U.S.

laws.summary: Rhode Island requires employers to provide wage ranges to applicants upon request and prior to discussing compensation, and to employees upon request.
requirements: Employers must provide wage range for a position upon applicant’s request
Wage range must be provided before discussing compensation
Employees may request and receive the wage range for their current position
Employers may not prohibit employees from discussing wages
Retaliation for requesting wage information is prohibited
laws.notes: Rhode Island does not require pay ranges in all job postings, but disclosure is mandatory upon request.

laws.summary: Rhode Island restricts non-compete agreements for certain categories of employees and applies reasonableness standards for others.
requirements: Non-competes are prohibited for non-exempt employees under FLSA
Non-competes are prohibited for employees earning less than 250% of the federal poverty level
Non-competes are prohibited for minors and undergraduate/graduate student interns
For permitted employees, restrictions must be reasonable in scope and duration
Overly broad restrictions are unenforceable
laws.notes: Rhode Island is relatively employee-protective in its statutory limits on non-competes.

laws.summary: Rhode Island restricts criminal history inquiries under its ban-the-box law and requires compliance with FCRA when using third-party background check vendors.
laws.statute_citation: R.I. Gen. Laws § 28-5-7(7); Fair Credit Reporting Act (15 U.S.C. § 1681)
requirements: Employers may not inquire about criminal convictions on initial job applications
Criminal history inquiries may occur later in the hiring process
If using third-party background checks, written consent is required
Pre-adverse action notice must be provided with report and rights
Final adverse action notice must be provided if a negative decision is made
laws.notes: Applies broadly to private employers in Rhode Island.

laws.summary: Rhode Island mandates paid sick and safe leave and protects certain statutory leave rights.
laws.statute_citation: R.I. Gen. Laws § 28-57 et seq. (Healthy and Safe Families and Workplaces Act)
requirements: Employers with 18+ employees must provide paid sick and safe leave
Accrual is generally 1 hour per 35 hours worked
Up to 40 hours of paid leave per year required
Leave covers illness, preventive care, family care, and domestic violence situations
Employees are entitled to jury duty leave without retaliation
laws.notes: Paid sick leave must be reflected accurately in benefits sections of offer letters.

laws.summary: Rhode Island legalizes recreational cannabis but does not provide broad statutory employment protections for off-duty use.
requirements: Employers may maintain drug-free workplace policies
Employers may prohibit impairment during work hours
Employers may take action based on positive drug tests depending on policy
Policies must be applied consistently and in compliance with anti-discrimination laws
laws.notes: Rhode Island does not mandate protection for recreational cannabis use in employment.

laws.summary: Arbitration agreements are generally enforceable in Rhode Island if consistent with contract law and federal arbitration principles.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act; Rhode Island contract law
requirements: Agreement must be voluntary and clearly written
Must not be unconscionable
Must provide reasonable notice
Courts may invalidate overly one-sided clauses

laws.summary: Rhode Island follows the at-will employment doctrine, subject to statutory, contractual, and public policy exceptions.
requirements: Employment is presumed at-will unless contract specifies otherwise
Cannot terminate for discriminatory reasons
Cannot retaliate for protected activity
Public policy exceptions apply
Employee handbooks may create implied contractual obligations
laws.notes: Clear at-will language in offer letters is recommended.

laws.summary: Rhode Island law prohibits employment discrimination on a broad range of protected characteristics.
laws.statute_citation: R.I. Gen. Laws § 28-5-1 et seq. (Fair Employment Practices Act)
requirements: Cannot discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation
Cannot discriminate based on age, disability, national origin, ancestry
Cannot discriminate based on marital status or domestic violence victim status
Harassment is prohibited
Retaliation for protected activity is prohibited
laws.notes: Rhode Island provides broad civil rights protections beyond federal minimums.
